There's no way to have Heritrix automatically direct its output to the 
disks with remaining space; the specification of target paths is manual 
configuration.

And, Heritrix won't always recover well from running out of space, 
because it can happen deep in IO-dependent logic that is not easily 
recoverable with a retry once the low-space condition is fixed. (A 
failure while writing W/ARCs or 'scratch' data *may* be recoverable with 
only a small amount of lost/corrupt URI data, but any failure writing to 
the 'state' directory will foul the current crawl.)

Our usual practice is to:

(1) export data from the most quickly-filled volumes (targets of W/ARC 
data) during the crawl, generally as soon as each file is completed

(2) monitor the disk space, and emergency-pause the crawl when space 
gets low

There is some code in the distribution (LowDiskPauseProcessor in 
H1-3.0.0, DiskSpaceMonitor in TRUNK) to help do part (2) above from 
within the crawler process, but our production crawls have used external 
scripts/monitoring instead.

Another option that you might want to consider if you have full control 
over the machine configuration would be to combine all local disks into 
one RAID volume; then usage is level across all disks automatically.

- Gordon @ IA
